content.description: This is an easy fist/offwidth crack.
This is an easy hand crack.

This problem traverses into the topout of

Warmup #1

from the left. Sit start in the crack, and move along a decent rail until you meet back up with the finish of

Warmup #1

. If this problem were to see more traffic, it could clean up nicely!
This is a fun hand crack that starts with a great fingerlock. The crux is the first move. The sit start variation goes at V2.
content.location:
This is the hand crack on the southwest end of the warmup wall. It faces northwest. It is just across from the

Suzuki Flare

.

content.description: This is an awesome, overhung handcrack that exits on the topout of the offwidth to its left. After the hand crack ends, there are a few crimps that make the transition to the flared topout easier.
content.location:
This route is in the cave.  Walk under the roof where

Hand Banana

is located, as soon as you reach the other side there is a hand crack on the left side.

content.description: This is an amazing, flared hand crack! The climbing is moderate up until about halfway up the route, where you get an excellent hand jam. After the hand jam, the crack becomes more narrow and flared all the way until the finish, where it becomes almost useless - thank God for the crystals! Super exciting and unique!
content.protection:
Small cams, TCUs, and nuts for the constrictions (0.5 and smaller) at the back of the flare. Bring a #1 or #2 for the start.

Per

Crackson

: there are now bolted anchors at the top of the formation above the crack.
content.location: This route starts on top of a large boulder, at the southwest end of the formation.

climbs.name: Simiantics
climbs.fa: Justin Edl, Brian Vansickle, Jason Anderson, 2007

content.description: This is the other side of Hand Bannana.  Start on the fists at the bottom of Hand Bannana and kick into the offwidth below and in front of you.  Follow the offwidth as it goes down and around the bulge, eventually narrowing to fists and then flared tight hands as the angle eases up.  The crux on this is probably somewhat fist size specific, the larger your hands, the easier this problem will be.  Very fun and physical.
content.location:
Find

Hand Banana

, and go under it. Turn around, and you will be facing it.

content.description: Shorty is a fun but short hand crack, which is a great way to warm up or top out the formation. A slight flare keeps this route interesting and gives it the grade of 5.8, despite it being a less than vertical hand crack.
content.location: This route is in the center of the southeast fast of the formation. Scramble up a short slab, then walk through a small chimney and scramble up to the start, atop a left-leaning boulder.

content.description: This is an absolutely beautiful splitter on perfect granite.  It starts out fists and goes quickly into offwidth, and it's on a slightly overhanging wall.  Probably a bit of a sandbag, but a good one to do if you want an introduction into the harder stuff because it has everything from stacks to classic offwidth wiggling.  This is a must for anyone interested in Vedauwoo's offwidths.
content.protection: A #5 and #6 Friend, plus the green or more preferably the blue Big Bro or equivalent for the top section.  Gear anchor, walk off.
content.location: This route is actually nowhere near the Third Lost Wall.  It's actually  miles to the east.  Nonetheless, if coming from I-80, park as for the directions here (700i) or take a right at the next road and park at the end of it.  In either case, walk to the northeast side of the field that sits generally to the east of the parking area.  At the end of the field, cross the stream and pick up a trail shortly thereafter.  Follow the trail, taking any right-trending forks.  After about a mile or more, you will come to a spike of rock sitting on a hilltop with a sharp drop off on one side.  Only The Lonely is on the clean north face of this spike.

climbs.name: One in Three Chance of Getting Your Dick Ripped Off

content.description:
This is ascends a slightly overhanging handcrack and is just like a slightly smaller

Plumb Line

. Climb thin hands at the bottom and wide hands to fists at the top.
content.protection: A pad. The landing kind of sucks. Putting your pad in the hole at the base is probably your best bet. I wouldn't want to fall from the top.
content.location:
It is smack dab in the middle of the Spaghetti Formation. From the approach, scramble in through a few blocks just left of the obvious, wide crack (which is a fun 5.10 offwidth on its own). One in Three... sits back in this corridor

Scramble off.

content.description: This is a vexing problem.  Start on the lower flared hand and the good fingerlock.  Figure out the footwork and the flared jams only to find yourself on a slab top-out.  It is a great problem to work till your fingers feel like they will fall off.
content.location: You can get to this route by walking up the ramp on the Northeast end of the formation.  Walking South along the rock this problem is the obvious, flared hands crack with a large, dead tree 10 feet behind it.

content.description: Knives Out is a fun, inversion problem that is a great warm up for other stuff in the area.  Bigger feet might be helpful.
content.location:
If you're looking at the start of

Simiantics

, turn around, walk a little bit and look left.

content.description: Karl ascends a 20 foot offwidth. It is mostly #5 Camalot sized; a good crack for practicing stacking. This is hardest right off of the ground.
content.protection: A pad, this could be lead with a #5 and #6 Camalot.
content.location: It is on the West face of the Spaghetti formation and is visible from the approach.

content.description: Hand Banana is a very steep fist crack. Start under the roof, work your way out this strenous, fist crack. The crux comes after pulling the lip, as this is very deceiving.
content.location: This route faces Northwest. It is on the top of the Southeast end of the formation. It has a very good, even landing underneath.

content.description: This is another Vedauwoo crimper/crystal puller with a few fun cobbles along the way! The crux is between the only two bolts on the route. Get high feet, and go for it!
content.protection: Small cams for the first 15 feet, followed by 2 bolts out to the right for the last half of the climb.
content.location:
This route shares the start with

First World Problem

and traverses right into a line of two bolts, which follows the blunt buttress to the top.

content.description:
This excellent and varied climb has a little bit of everything: hands, fingers, face, and even a fist!

Start at the bottom of a narrow corridor. The crux comes early. See the photos on this page for more beta on its location.
content.protection:
Bolted anchors were installed on 9/25/14, allowing for a safe descent for this climb, the offwidths to the right, and '

Death by Hantavirus

'.
content.location: This climb is on the Northwest side of the formation. You can see it as you approach the formation, on its North East end. The climb starts at the bottom of a narrow corridor.

content.description: This is the lightning bolt finger crack which fractures out towards the right. Follow the crack until it moves around the arete, then finish up easy 5th class terrain. The off width pod about 20ft up is deceivingly trickyÂ… The rock quality is excellent inside most of the crack, but the face is in need of some cleaning. Beware of a questionable block as you follow the crack around the arete.
content.protection:
Standard rack with an emphasis on finger sized pieces for the first 30 feet. Bolted anchors have been added to the top of '

First World Problem

', which can be accessed from the top of 'Death by Hantavirus'. Descending from the tops of the climb is now easy!
content.location: This route is close to the northeast end of the formation, on the southeast face.
